message.content: We refer to an article on LFA-1 integrin deficiency on Medscape for help. The correct answer is (B), which describes the presentation of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1, which is caused by defective LFA-1 integrin. Option (A) describes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, (C) describes DiGeorge syndrome, and (D) describes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), none of which are associated with LFA-1 integrin deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein is important for phagocyte function, and defects in this protein can lead to recurrent bacterial infections. Option B is correct, as skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation are characteristic of a defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes, along with the recurrent bacterial infections. Option A describes findings in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Option C describes DiGeorge syndrome, and Option D describes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes leads to leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1. Among the options, skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation are characteristic of this condition. Option A refers to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, option C refers to DiGeorge syndrome, and option D refers to severe combined immunodeficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes suggests leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD). Among the options, only (B) skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation are associated with LAD. The other options describe different conditions with their own set of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, type 1. Recurrent bacterial infections are the hallmark feature, and skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation are common. The other answer options are associated with different diseases: (A) eczema and thrombocytopenia are seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, (C) cardiac defects, hypoparathyroidism, palatal defects, and learning disabilities are seen in DiGeorge Syndrome, and (D) chronic diarrhea, oral candidiasis, and absent thymic shadow are characteristic of severe combined immunodeficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The defective LFA-1 integrin protein on phagocytes is characteristic of leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1). Recurrent bacterial infections are a common symptom, and skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilical separation are also commonly seen in LAD-1. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, while cardiac defects, hypoparathyroidism, palatal defects, and learning disabilities are associated with DiGeorge syndrome. Chronic diarrhea, oral candidiasis, severe infections since birth, and absent thymic shadow are associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The defective LFA-1 integrin protein on phagocytes is characteristic of leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1). Recurrent bacterial infections are the most common feature, but skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation is also a common symptom of LAD-1. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, cardiac defects and learning disabilities are associated with DiGeorge syndrome, and chronic diarrhea, oral candidiasis, severe infections since birth, and absent thymic shadow are associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The correct option is (B), which refers to leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1. Infants with this condition have an absence or decrease in pus formation and delayed umbilical cord separation, in addition to recurrent bacterial infections. Eczema and thrombocytopenia are not specific for LAD. Option (C) refers to DiGeorge syndrome and (D) refers to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency. Patients with this condition will have recurrent bacterial infections and skin infections with absent pus formation, delayed umbilicus separation due to impaired migration of leukocytes into tissue. None of the other options listed are associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Defective LFA-1 integrin (CD18) protein on phagocytes is a characteristic of leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1. Option B is the correct answer as it describes skin infections with absent pus formation and delayed umbilicus separation, which are common findings in this condition. Options A, C, and D describe different conditions with different presentations.
